subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA Keyboard layout
msgSnippet: So now we have two new proposals, yours and Peter Guiness s. How are we to evaluate them? Again, we all have unique linguistic backgrounds. Having studied
messageBody:
So now we have two new proposals, yours and Peter Guiness's. How are
we to evaluate them?

Again, we all have unique linguistic backgrounds. Having studied
German, I like using 'j' for #17, for instance. I don't know the
history of the IPA, but I wouldn't be surprised to find that the
examples of German and the Romance Languages had a major influence.
And, as your assignment of 'J' to #30 shows, there's simply not going
to be a mapping that pleases all of the people all of the time.

For this reason I abandoned my own attempt to do this, and looked for
a standard we could use. I continue to advocate QS-SAMPA.

Ted


On Dec 9, 2007 12:25 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > OK, Paul. Keep going. It's difficult for the rest of us to evaluate
> > your proposal until you've assigned keys for the entire alphabet.
> >
>
> Everything else remains the same. So:
>
> Pipe => p
> Bob => b
> Tut => t
> Deed => d
> Kick => k
> Gig => g
> Thoth => T
> Thither => D
> Fife => f
> Valve => v
> Sis => s
> Zoos => z
> Shush => S
> Zhivago => Z
> Church => c
>
> Judge => j
> Yo-yo => y
> Win-win => w
> Whitewheat => W
> Ha-ha => h
> Inkling => N
> Mime => m
> Nun => n
> Loll => l
> Roar => r
> KIT (if) => i
> FLEECE (Eat) => Y
> DRESS (Ed) => e
> FACE (Age) => E
> TRAP (Ash) => J (yuck!)
> PRICE (Ice) => I
> PALM (Ah) => A
> THOUGHT (Awl) => O
> LOT (On) => Q (yuck!)
> CHOICE (Oil) => R (yuck!)
> Ado => a
> MOUTH (Out) => H (yuck)
> GOAT (Oak) => o
> FOOT (Wool) => U
> GOOSE (Ooze) => u
>
> This mapping has 4 letters that has nothing to do with the Lexical sets
> (or sounds or how we think of the letter in TO). On the other hand, as I
> wrote before, I stays as I, y stays as y, j stays as j, and the "a" as
> we think of it in the indefinite pronoun stays the same.
>
> Paul
>

So now we have two new proposals, yours and Peter Guiness's. How are
we to evaluate them?

Again, we all have unique linguistic backgrounds. Having studied
German, I like using 'j' for #17, for instance. I don't know the
history of the IPA, but I wouldn't be surprised to find that the
examples of German and the Romance Languages had a major influence.
And, as your assignment of 'J' to #30 shows, there's simply not going
to be a mapping that pleases all of the people all of the time.

For this reason I abandoned my own attempt to do this, and looked for
a standard we could use. I continue to advocate QS-SAMPA.

Ted
